statement:
If in the open interval $I$, all the of the series $$\begin{aligned}
          f_1(x)\!+\!f_2(x)\!+\cdots
  \end{aligned}$$ have continuous derivatives, the series converges
having sum $S(x)$ and the differentiated series
$f_1'(x)\!+\!f_2'(x)\!+\!\cdots$ on the interval $I$, then the series
(1) can be differentiated termwise, i.e. in every point of $I$ the sum
function $S(x)$ is differentiable and
$$\frac{d\,S(x)}{dx} = f_1'(x)\!+\!f_2'(x)\!+\cdots$$ The situation
implies also that the series (1) converges uniformly on $I$.
